citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available at time of this inspection. A total of 263 guinea pigs were
counted during the inspection. There were no inventory records kept since June 2023 indicating the number of adult
guinea pigs, weanlings, and newborns held, raised, or born. Failure to maintain these records can make it difficult to
assess the health of the caviary by identifying losses by decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. The licensee
must keep and maintain records containing the required information which disclose the number of guinea pigs, held,
owned, acquired, or disposed of including births and deaths. Correct by August 14, 2023.

There are accumulations of excreta and soiled bedding in 22 of 25 guinea pig weanling enclosures. Accumulations of
feces and soiled bedding can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards such as bacterial and fungal diseases. The
weanling enclosures were last cleaned on Tuesday (8/1/2023), and are housing an average of 10 weanlings per
enclosure. The cleaning frequency is not effective in removing the fecal accumulations and soiled bedding inside the
enclosures. Primary enclosures must be cleaned often enough to prevent fecal and soiled bedding accumulations inside
enclosures, and must be sanitized at least every 2 weeks. Licensee must ensure that enclosures are cleaned when dirty.
Correct by August 8, 2023.

Housekeeping. There are accumulations of shavings, excreta and food debris on the floor in front of the row of guinea pig
enclosures. Animal facilities must be kept clean to prevent pest problems, odors, and unnecessary disease risks. Correct
by ensuing animal rooms are kept clean, including: removing accumulations of shavings, excreta, and food debris from
the floor; routinely dusting off wire surfaces and racks; and maintaining a level of general cleanliness to support good
animal husbandry and health. Correct by August 8, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
